All the spectra are reported after subtracting the spectrum of the sample prior CO dosing. The insets show the evolution of the spectra in the ν(OH) region: activated catalyst (black), after CO adsorption (dark grey) and stepwise outgassing (light grey). A series of NiSO4-ReOx/Al2O3 catalysts were synthesized by a co-impregnation method, tested in the conversion of ethylene to propylene at mild conditions, and thoroughly characterized by different spectroscopy techniques. In particular, the attention was focused on the NiSO4 function, which is directly involved in ethylene conversion to 2-butylene, but also drives the catalyst deactivation. Results shows that the sulfate anions increase the surface acidity of alumina, and simultaneously influence the electronic properties of the Ni sites. Indeed, thermal activation of the catalyst promotes the formation of covalent bonds between the sulfate anions and the Ni2+ or Al3+ cations, while keeping constant the + 2 oxidation state of the Ni sites. Studying the initial steps of the ETP reaction reveals the primary acid-catalyzed formation of branched oligomers. Catalyst deactivation could be due to formation and adsorption of long-chain oligomers, or less interaction of sulfate anions with Ni ions. Graphical Abstract NiSO4-ReOx/γ-Al2O3 tandem catalyst has been studied by different spectroscopy techniques during thermal activation and interaction with ethylene. The results indicates that deactivation is mainly the consequence of adsorption of higher linear ethylene oligomers or due to Ni2+ sites not being anymore interacted with the sulfate ions. Improvement in the catalyst lifetime could be achieved by limiting the mobility of the sulfate anions. ga1 Keywords Ethylene Propylene Bimetallic Nickel Rhenium Sulfate 1 Introduction Ethylene and propylene are key petrochemical building blocks produced by steam cracking of hydrocarbons; propylene being a by-product of ethylene production [1]. Recently, the average global growth rate of polypropylene production has overtaken that of polyethylene creating a supply/demand gap for propylene [2]. Furthermore, as oil and gas are substituted by shale gas derived ethane, the propylene gap is expected to widen. Hence there is a need for direct conversion of ethylene to propylene (ETP). Moreover, production of ethylene from (bio)ethanol has been commercialized years ago and ETP process can offer an approach to produce bio-propylene and many other chemicals from renewable bioethanol [3]. Currently, this is achieved through Olefin Conversion Technology (OCT) process, that consists of an ethylene dimerization unit in upstream of an OCT metathesis plant, which provide the 2-butylene needed for conversion of ethylene and butylene in the OCT’s metathesis reaction system [4]. However, it would be highly desirable to reduce this complex process to a single reactor technology, using a single catalyst with a dual function. Such a process would also open a sustainable and ‘compact’ route to bio-ethanol derived propylene. Early studies have shown molybdenum and tungsten supported metal oxides to convert ethylene to propylene at low yield [5–7]. Different protonated zeolites with MOR, BEA, MFI and CHA [8,9] framework are also reported to be active in ETP at relatively high temperature of 673–723 K. Among them, small pore zeolites like SAPO-34 [8,10,11] and SSZ-13 [8] show high selectivity to propylene (>68%). In addition, different Ni-exchanged microporous / mesoporous aluminosilicates [12–17], NiO/PdO-Re2O7/B2O3-Al2O3 mixed compounsd [18,19], and nickel-molybdenum mesoporous catalysts [20,21] are also investigated as a catalyst for the ETP reaction. Majority of them are reviewed in a recent paper by Blay et al. [8] and details of their performance including the activity temperature, conversation and selectivity are listed in a table for comparison. We previously reported a highly selective NiSO4-ReOx/γ-Al2O3 catalyzed tandem reaction of ethylene dimerization/metathesis to propylene at mild conditions [22]. Comparing to the intensively studied system of Ni/acid zeolites and Ni-MCM-41, this material catalyze the ETP reaction at much lower temperature (323–373 K in comparison with 673–723 K for zeolites) with comparable level of yield and selectivity [8]. This system contains in the same catalytic body two components well known for their respective functions. As a matter of fact, nickel-based ethylene dimerization catalysts have been known for a long time [4]. The highly active co-catalyst free NiSO4/γ-Al2O3 has been reported [23–27] for light alkene dimerization or oligomerization already 20 years ago. On the other hand, the Re2O7/γ-Al2O3 function represents a typical olefin metathesis catalyst operating at low temperature in the range of 293–393 K [28–32]. Although highly selective in the ETP reaction, our NiSO4/ReOx/γ-Al2O3 catalyst suffers from fast deactivation, which is driven by the ethylene dimerization step. Hence, insight into the NiSO4 based ethylene dimerization step is needed. Recently, similar cascade catalyst based on Ni and Re as active component have been also reported for ETP reaction under mild condition [33–35]. Ni-based olefin oligomerization catalysts such as NiO-SiO2 [36], NiO/SiO2-Al2O3 [37–39], NiSO4/SiO2-Al2O3 [40,41], NiSO4/γ-Al2O3 [23–25] and Ni2+/zeolites [42–46] have been widely studied. The oxidation state of the Ni sites largely depends on the support materials and the promoters used in the catalysts [47]. For the NiSO4/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, a low valent Ni site, possibly Ni+, combined with surface acidity has been reported to be the active catalyst site responsible for the dimerization reaction [23,25]. It was also found that the reaction mechanism changes when oligomerizing alkenes with different numbers of carbon atoms [48]. However, the nature of active sites of NiSO4/γ-Al2O3 at a molecular level and in particular the role of [SO4]2- is still little understood. We now report for the first time a systematic experimental study on the NiSO4/ReOx/γ-Al2O3 catalyst and concentrate especially on the NiSO4 site. The investigation on the molecular nature of the active dimerization site is carried out by means of in-situ FT-IR and UV-Vis-NIR spectroscopies, following the course of thermal catalyst activation and including subsequent CO adsorption at low temperature (100 K) and reactivity in the presence of C2H4. This approach allows monitoring the changes occurring in the coordination structure of the Ni sites, in the population of the surface hydroxyl groups on γ-Al2O3, as well as in the symmetry of surface [SO4]2- anions during the catalyst activation. It is worth noticing that CO adsorption on Ni-based catalysts at a low temperature (100 K) decreases the possibility of reduction of Ni2+ compared with room temperature and enables to detect both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites. Moreover, the time-resolved experiments during reaction with C2H4 provide a possibility to understand the dimerization initiation reaction and gain insight into the catalyst deactivation. Finally, in-situ XPS and ESR measurements on the NiSO4/γ-Al2O3 catalyst were carried out in order to investigate the oxidation state of Ni. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts’ preparation Catalysts based on γ-Al2O3 containing nickel sulfate and rhenium oxide were prepared by the co-impregnation method. The detailed synthetic procedures have been described in the previous paper [22]. The precursors of nickel sulfate and rhenium oxide were nickel (II) sulfate hexahydrate (Sigma-Aldrich, purity: ≥ 99.99%) and ammonium perrhenate (Sigma-Aldrich, purity: ≥ 99%) and used as received. The catalysts with separately active components were prepared in the same way and impregnated with an aqueous solution of NiSO4.6 H2O, (NH4)2SO4 (Sigma-Aldrich, purity: ≥ 99%), [NH4][ReO4] and Ni(NO3)2.7 H2O (Sigma-Aldrich, purity ≥ 99%), respectively. Before any test, surface areas of samples have been determined using N2 isotherm and Brunauer, Emmett and Taylor (BET) approach. N2 adsorption isotherm measured at liquid nitrogen temperature (77 K) on a Flows orbⅢ− 2310 instrument. The catalysts were outgassed at 573 K before the test. 2.2 Methods 2.2.1 FT-IR spectroscopy In situ FT-IR experiments have been performed with the dual aim to characterize the catalysts and to follow the reaction with ethylene. FT-IR spectra were recorded in transmission mode on a Bruker Vertex 70 spectrometer equipped with a mercury cadmium telluride cryo-detector, at a resolution of 4 cm-1. The general procedure was as follows. A thin, self-supporting wafer of the catalyst, placed in an infrared cell designed to allow in-situ temperature treatment and gas dosage, was activated under vacuum at 673 K for 1 h. FT-IR spectra were collected during the thermal treatment at regular temperature interval. The FT-IR spectrum of the calcinated catalyst was then collected at room temperature. In order to characterize the surface properties of the catalysts, CO adsorption experiments were performed at 100 K. To this aim, CO was sent into the cell at room temperature, followed by cooling to 100 K. FT-IR spectra were collected at the maximum CO coverage and for successive controlled gas evacuation steps, up to the complete desorption of CO. The reactivity of the catalysts towards ethylene at room temperature was investigated by dosing ethylene at an initial equilibrium pressure of Pethylene = 10 mbar and collecting FT-IR spectra at regular time intervals for 2 h. The equilibrium pressure was then increased to Pethylene= 40 mbar and the reaction was monitored for another 2 h. At this point ethylene was evacuated and CO was sent into the cell again followed by cooling to 100 K. The FT-IR experiment of CO adsorption was repeated as discussed above. 2.2.2 Diffuse reflectance (DR) UV-Vis-NIR spectroscopy DR UV-Vis-NIR spectra were collected on a Varian Cary 5000 instrument, at spectral resolution of 2 nm. Approximately 1 g of sample was introduced into a cell equipped with a suprasil quartz window specially designed for in-situ gas dosage. The samples were outgassed in-situ overnight and successively degassed at 673 K for 2 h. DR UV-Vis-NIR spectra of the calcinated catalysts were collected at room temperature before and after reaction with ethylene at room temperature overnight. 2.2.3 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) XPS analysis of the catalyst sample was conducted on an Axis UltraDLD XP spectrometer (Kratos Analytical). The XPS spectra were taken by using monochromatic Al Kα radiation, at pressures of 6 × 10-8 Torr - 6 × 10-9 Torr in the analysis chamber. The instrument resolution was determined as the full width at half maximum (FWHM) of the Ag 3d5/2 peak. The fresh catalyst sample was outgassed in the analysis chamber followed by in-situ activation under nitrogen flow at 473 K and 673 K for 1 h. Also an XPS spectrum of the spent catalyst collected from the continuous flow reactor test (as reported in the previous paper [22]) was collected. To this aim, the spent catalyst was removed from the reactor under inert conditions. 2.2.4 Electron spin resonance (ESR) ESR measurements were performed at both room temperature and liquid nitrogen temperature using a X-band Bruker EleXsySES60 spectrometer and a special designed cell for in-situ evacuation, heat treatment and ethylene dosage. The catalyst sample was activated in the cell under vacuum at 673 K for 2 h before being cooled to room temperature for measurements. Subsequently, 100 mbar of ethylene was sent to the in-situ cell and the catalyst was measured 10 min later. Thereafter, the cell was cooled to liquid nitrogen temperature and a new measurement was taken. After warming the cell to room temperature, the described measurement cycle was repeated one more at both liquid nitrogen temperature and room temperature. EPR spectra of the spent catalyst were collected without exposing the catalyst to air. 2.2.5 Analysis of deactivated catalysts Powder samples of deactivated catalysts were obtained from a self-designed static reactor after 24 h ethylene reaction at 323 K. After reaction, the reactor was cooled down in an ice-water bath and CH2Cl2 was injected into the reactor to dissolve the soluble products. The extraction was analyzed by GC-MS. The GC-MS instrument was an Agilent 7890 A gas chromatograph coupled with a 5975 C mass spectrometer. 1 μL of solution was injected each time by an automatic liquid sampler and analyzed by a HP-PLOT Al2O3/KCl column. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance Table 1 shows the prepared catalyst compositions, which also indicates the different impregnation order and the nominal weight percentage of active components contained in the catalysts. For instance, 8 wt%-NiSO4/8 wt%-ReOx/γ-Al2O3 means that the NiSO4.7 H2O solution was impregnated first, followed by Impregnation by [NH4][ReO4] solution, with 8 wt% Ni corresponding to the NiSO4/γ-Al2O3 part and 8 wt% ReOx corresponding to the whole catalyst, respectively. 4 Not measured The catalysts shown in Table 2 were tested in a continuous flow reactor. Among them, 8 wt%-NiSO4/8 wt%-ReOx/γ-Al2O3 and 8 wt%-ReOx/8 wt%-NiSO4/γ-Al2O3 catalysts exhibited similar performance. The 8 wt%-NiSO4/γ-Al2O3 catalyst demonstrated a strong activity for ethylene dimerization, while 8 wt%-NiO/γ-Al2O3 showed no activity without modification with [SO4]2-. Moreover, no oligomeric products were detected on 10 wt%-ReOx/γ-Al2O3 when exposed to ethylene feed. This observation supports our earlier finding [22] about the roles of the active metal sites, where the Ni function is responsible for the dimerization reaction and the Re function catalyzes the metathesis reaction. Moreover, [SO4]2- plays an essential role in the ETP reaction since we observe no activity for sulfate free samples at low temperatures. 4.1 Effects of thermal activation on vibrational and electronic properties of the catalysts All catalysts have been subjected to a complete spectroscopic characterization both before and after thermal activation at 673 K. Elemental analysis from the previous paper [22] showed that there was no material (Re, Ni, S) loss during the calcination procedure. The FT-IR spectra of all the samples are dominated by physisorbed water (broad absorption band in the 3700 – 2500 cm-1 region due to the ν(OH) vibrational mode, and a band at 1635 cm-1 due to the δ(HOH) vibrational mode). Activation at 673 K causes substantial changes in the FT-IR spectra of all the catalysts. Fig. 1a shows the evolution of the FT-IR spectra during thermal activation for the 8 wt%-NiSO4/γ-Al2O3 catalyst as an example, while Fig. 1b and c show the FT-IR spectra of all the activated samples in the 3900 – 3000 cm-1 and 1600 – 1200 cm-1 regions, respectively. During the activation, the physically adsorbed water is removed, as testified by the disappearance of the δ(HOH) absorption band at 1635 cm-1 and by the gradual decrease of the ν(OH) absorption band (Fig. 1a). In the ν(OH) region, five absorption bands are clearly observed in the spectrum of activated alumina, which reveal the presence of both bridged (more acidic) and terminal (less acidic) hydroxyl species, in agreement with previous studies [49,50]. In contrast, for all the other activated samples, only a weak and broad absorption band is observed in the ν(OH) region around 3500 cm-1, indicating that the remaining hydroxyl groups at the alumina surface are still H-bonded. Interestingly, for all the Ni-containing catalysts and for the 8 wt%-(NH4)2SO4/γ-Al2O3 sample, the disappearance of the absorption bands assigned to physically adsorbed water is accompanied by the appearance of a well-defined band just below 1400 cm-1 (Fig. 1c). The connection between the two phenomena is demonstrated by a clear isosbestic point around 1400 cm-1 (Fig. 1a). This band is assigned to the asymmetric stretching vibration of the [SO4]2- anion, whose symmetry decreases upon water removal. Indeed, an [SO4]2- anion in perfect tetrahedral environment gives a single ν(SO4) asymmetric vibration band around 1100 cm-1 [51]. However, this band splits into multiple bands upon decreasing the symmetry on all the Ni-containing samples (i.e. by going from an ionic to a covalently bonded sulfate), the νasym(SO4) mode being expected near 1400 cm-1 and the νsym(SO4) mode around 1200 cm-l (and hence covered by the out-of-scale absorption band of bulk alumina) [52]. The FT-IR spectrum of activated 8 wt%-(NH4)2SO4/γ-Al2O3 sample shows well-defined bands in this spectral region, which indicate the presence of two kinds of SO4 species, namely monodentate species (accounting for the bands at 1403 and 1426 cm-1) and bidentate species (accounting for the bands at 1381, 1284 and 1244 cm-1) [52]. Hence, we can conclude that dehydration at 673 K causes a change in the symmetry of the sulfate anions in all the sulfated samples. Small differences are observed in the width and position of the corresponding absorption bands among the different samples, indicating that the surroundings of the [SO4]2- anions is not exactly the same and it is likely to be influenced by the presence of the metal phases. Complementary information was obtained by means of DR UV-Vis-NIR, XPS and ESR experiments. Fig. 2a shows the DR UV-Vis-NIR spectra of all the samples before activation. Generally speaking, the very intense (often out-of-scale) absorptions above 26,000 cm-1 are due to charge-transfer transitions. The bands observed in the 26,000–8000 cm-1 region are assigned to d-d transitions. Finally, the narrow and weak absorptions in the NIR region (8000 – 4000 cm-1) are due to the combination and/or overtones of vibrational modes involving mainly OH groups. The UV-Vis-NIR spectra of bare alumina and 8 wt%-(NH4)2SO4/γ-Al2O3 do not absorb in the UV and Vis region, but only weak bands are observed around 7000 and 5100 cm-1, which are assigned respectively to the ν(OH)+ δ(HOH) and 2ν(OH) vibrational modes related to physisorbed water. The spectrum of 10 wt%-ReOx/γ-Al2O3 shows a very intense absorption in the UV-region (above 30,000 cm-1), easily ascribed to the charge-transfer transition of rhenium oxide [53]. In contrast, the spectra of all the samples containing nickel display three well defined bands in the region of d-d transitions, centered around 8650 cm-1 (band O1, 3A2 g(F)→3T2 g(F)), 13,700–15,050 cm-1 (band O2, 3A2 g(F)→3T1g(F) and 3A2 g(F)→1Eg(D)), and 25,260 cm-1 (band O3, 3A2 g(F)→3T1 g(P)) [54–56]. The same three bands are observed in the spectrum of a NiSO4.6 H2O reference sample at 8500, 14,100–15,300 and 25,800 cm-1 (Fig. 2(4)). Hence, DR UV-Vis-NIR spectroscopy provides evidence that the Ni2+ cations in the Ni-containing samples display a 6-fold coordination and that all the coordination vacancies are filled by water molecules [57]. As for the FT-IR spectra described above, also the DR UV-Vis spectra greatly change upon thermal activation, and in particular those of the samples containing the nickel. Fig. 2b shows the evolution of the DR UV-Vis spectra for 8 wt%-NiSO4/γ-Al2O3 as an example, whereas the spectra of the other activated samples are reported in Fig. S1. After outgassing 8 wt%-NiSO4/γ-Al2O3 overnight at room temperature, a small fraction of physically adsorbed water is removed, resulting in a blue shift of all the d-d bands and decrease of the bands related to OH vibrations in the NIR region. After activation at 673 K, most of the water is removed. Simultaneously, the d-d bands greatly change, both in position and in intensity. The new spectrum is indicative of the presence of Ni2+ sites with a symmetry lower than in the hydrated sample, in analogy to what is reported by Cornet et al. [58] for a similar NiO/Al2O3 sample activated at 723 K, but contradicts the works of both Cai et al. [23] and Sohn et al. [25], who reported reduction of Ni2+ to Ni+ by calcination of a NiSO4/γ-Al2O3 catalyst at 873 K. In order to definitely assign the oxidation state of the Ni sites after catalyst activation, we analyzed the 8 wt%-NiSO4/γ-Al2O3 catalyst also by XPS and ESR spectroscopy. The Ni 2p XPS spectra of fresh and activated 8 wt%-NiSO4/γ-Al2O3 catalyst are shown in Fig. 3a. The spectrum of the fresh catalyst (Fig. 3a, spectrum 1) shows the Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2 core level lines at 856.8 and 875.0 eV, and the shake-up satellites at the typical 6 eV binding energy difference relative to the corresponding main lines [59]. This line pattern is attributed to the presence of Ni2+ ions on γ-Al2O3, and is in good agreement with the results reported by Dufresne et al. [60] and Nikolova et al. [61]. The spectrum of 8 wt%-NiSO4/γ-Al2O3 does not change after calcination for 1 h at 473 K (Fig. 3a, spectrum 2). A slight peak shift to lower binding energy of about 0.4 eV is observed after thermal activation at 673 K (Fig. 3a, spectrum 3). This shift indicates a small change in the electronic structure of the Ni ions, likely because of the changes occurring to the adjacent sulfate ions or surface hydroxyl groups but is not compatible with the reduction of Ni2+ to Ni+ sites. Indeed, the energy difference of Ni 2p3/2 lines for reference Ni0 vs Ni2+ species is approximately 2.3 eV, as reported for Ni/Al2O3 or Ni/SiO2 systems [62,63]. Hence, we can conclude that in the adopted experimental conditions, the Ni2+ sites preserve their oxidation state also after catalyst activation. This is further confirmed by the ESR measurements. Indeed, the ESR spectrum of activated 8 wt%-NiSO4/γ-Al2O3 catalyst (Fig. 3b, spectra 2 and 3) is the same as for the fresh catalyst, and only a higher resolution is obtained by measurement at liquid nitrogen temperature. This indicates that Ni+ is not produced during catalyst activation at 673 K. Taken together, the spectroscopic data discussed above indicate that the Ni2+ sites in hydrated samples display a 6-fold coordination with all the coordination vacancies filled by water molecules. The [SO4]2- counter-anions are in turn solvated by water molecules and not directly coordinated neither to the Ni2+ nor to the Al3+ cations. Upon thermal activation, coordinated water is gradually lost, implying the creation of some coordination vacancies around the Ni2+ sites, which however retain their oxidation state, as confirmed by both XPS and ESR spectroscopy. Simultaneously, it is expected that a small fraction of the Al3+ sites at the alumina surface are dehydroxylated and behave as strong Lewis sites. As a consequence, at least a fraction of the adjacent [SO4]2- ions are covalently bonded either to the Ni2+ or to the surface Al3+ cations, with a resulting decrease of symmetry and an enhancement of the covalent character. [52] where M represents the Ni2+ or Al3+ surface sites. In addition, the covalently bonded sulfate groups might be partially protonated by the surface OH groups, as suggested in the literature, and in agreement with our observation of an enhanced Brønsted acidity for sulfated catalysts (vide infra). As suggested by Davydov et al. [64] the Brønsted proton might be delocalized over the oxygen atoms of the covalent sulfate groups, as shown in the bottom part of Scheme 1. It is worth mentioning that, the dehydrated Ni cations are reported as the active species in the ethylene oligomerization [65] and they are covalently bonded to the O atoms of the matrix [66]. It is also outlined that isolated nickel cations (and not nickel oxide) are active in oligomerization [46,67]. As discussed, we believe that at least a fraction of the adjacent [SO4]2- ions after dehydration are covalently bonded to the Ni2+ cations (Scheme 1). Formation of these covalent bonds can explain the observed catalytic activity in samples containing NiSO4. 4.2 Probing the surface properties of the activated catalysts by means of FT-IR spectroscopy of CO adsorbed at 100 K In the next step, we investigated the surface properties of our catalysts by means of in-situ FT-IR spectroscopy of CO adsorbed at 100 K. This method has been widely applied to investigate Ni-containing catalysts [45,46,64,68–71], since it allows the determination of the Ni oxidation state in different conditions, according to the ν(CO) modes of the carbonyl complexes. Furthermore, the strengths of both Lewis and Brønsted acid sites can be simultaneously probed, since CO is also able to interact at 100 K with both the non-coordinated Al3+ (Lewis acid) surface sites and hydroxyl groups (Brønsted acid) at the surface of acid catalysts, forming ≡ Al3+···CO adducts and ≡ Al-OH···CO adducts, respectively. The sequence of FT-IR spectra of CO adsorbed at 100 K on all the investigated samples as a function of the CO coverage (θ) is shown in Fig. 4. In all the cases, the insets report the evolution of the FT-IR spectra in the ν(OH) region. The FT-IR spectra of CO adsorbed on bare alumina (Fig. 4a) display two main ν(CO) absorption bands, which are completely reversible upon degassing at 100 K. The first one, centered at 2154 cm-1 at θmax, is attributed to CO adsorbed on the surface hydroxyl groups [72]. Correspondingly, a perturbation of the ν(OH) bands is observed (inset in Fig. 4a). This band slightly shifts up to 2160 cm-1 upon decreasing θ and disappears fast. The second band, centered at 2186 cm-1 at θmax, is assigned to the CO adsorbed on the coordinatively unsaturated Al3+ ions. This band blue shifts up to 2202 cm-1 upon decreasing the CO coverage and it is more resistant at low temperature, witnessing a higher strength of interaction. The shift with decreasing θ is due to the vanishing of the lateral interaction between adjacent CO molecules, as widely documented in the literature [73,74]. Similar FT-IR spectra were obtained for CO adsorbed on the 8 wt%-(NH4)2SO4/γ-Al2O3 sample (Fig. 4b), except that the two main ν(CO) absorption bands are shifted at higher values compared to bare alumina and display a different relative intensity. In particular, the band attributed to ≡ Al-OH···CO adducts is observed at 2168 cm-1 at θmax and shifts to 2177 cm-1 at θmin. Correspondingly, the broad ν(OH) band downward shifts by approximate 70 cm-1. This behavior witnesses an enhanced Brønsted acidity for sulfated alumina, as widely reported in literature [52]. It is worth noticing that, although low temperature CO adsorption measures a medium-weak Brønsted acid strength, other methods indicate a much larger acidity [75–77]. The absorption band assigned to ≡ Al3+···CO adducts goes from 2203 cm-1 at θmax to 2212 cm-1 at θmin, indicating that the Al3+ sites are stronger Lewis acid sites than in bare alumina. This agrees with earlier reports [75,78]. The effect of the rhenium phase on the surface properties of the catalysts is much less pronounced than that of sulfates. The FT-IR spectra of CO adsorbed on 10 wt%-ReOx/γ-Al2O3 (Fig. 4c) almost exhibit the same behavior as pure alumina, except that the band assigned to ≡ Al3+···CO adducts is less intense relative to that due to ≡ Al-OH···CO adducts. This indicates that the ReOx phase partially covers the alumina surface. In contrast, the FT-IR spectra of CO adsorbed on 8 wt%-NiSO4/γ-Al2O3 (Figs. 4d), 8 wt%-NiSO4/8 wt%-ReOx/γ-Al2O3 (Figs. 4e) and 8 wt%-ReOx/8 wt%-NiSO4/γ-Al2O3 (Fig. 4f) catalysts are substantially different from those discussed above. Three main absorption bands are observed in all the three cases: 1) The most intense absorption band is centered around 2202 cm-1 at θmax and undergoes a pronounced shift upon decreasing θ down to about 2214 cm-1 at θmin. This band, which is also the most resistant to a decrease in θ, is assigned to CO adsorbed on coordinatively unsaturated Ni2+ sites and overlaps with the band ascribed to ≡ Al3+···CO adducts. 2) The band centered around 2162 cm-1 at θmax, which shifts to about 2170 cm-1 at θmin, is assigned to ≡ Al-OH···CO adducts. The Brønsted acidity of the surface hydroxyl groups is very weak, suggesting that the effect of sulfate anions on the properties of alumina is weaker in presence of the nickel phase than on sulfated alumina. 3) In addition, a broad band centered around 2143 cm-1 is observed in all the three cases, which is easily removable upon decreasing θ. This band is attributed to physisorbed CO and testifies that an increase in the complexity of catalyst formulation creates new opportunities for CO physisorption. It is important to point out that in all the three cases no bands ascribable to Ni+(CO)2 and Ni+(CO) species have been observed both at high and at low CO coverage, in well agreement with DR UV-Vis-NIR, XPS and ESR data. According to the specialized literature, Ni+(CO)2 species should give a doublet of bands at 2120 – 2080 cm-1 and 2145 – 2130 cm-1, while the Ni+(CO) species should absorb around 2100–2135 cm-1. In both cases the ν(CO) bands are rather resistant to desorption of CO not only at 100 K but even at room temperature [64,79]. In contrast, in our experiment all the observed absorption bands are easily reversible upon degassing at 100 K, indicating that they are not due to any Ni+ carbonyl species. Hence, we can conclude that Ni+ is not formed during the catalysts’ activation in our experimental conditions in well agreement with XPS and ESR data. Similarly, no band is attributed to CO adsorbed on Re cations (2500 – 1800 cm-1) in the spectra of 8 wt%-NiSO4/8 wt%-ReOx/γ-Al2O3 and 8 wt%-ReOx/8 wt%-NiSO4/γ-Al2O3 samples. The intensity of the bands attributed to ≡ Al-OH···CO adducts and to physisorbed CO relative to that of CO adsorbed on the Ni2+ cations is lower for 8 wt%-ReOx/8 wt%-NiSO4/γ-Al2O3 and 8 wt%-NiSO4/8 wt%-ReOx/γ-Al2O3 compared to 8 wt%-NiSO4/γ-Al2O3, which suggests that the rhenium phase deactivates or replaces some Brønsted sites. Finally, it is interesting to observe that on 8 wt%-(NH4)2SO4/γ-Al2O3 and Ni containing catalysts, adsorption of CO causes a perturbation of the absorption band around 1400 cm-1, previously ascribed to the νasym(SO4) vibrational mode of covalently bonded sulfate groups ( Fig. 5). This band downward shifts by around 10 cm-1 at θmax, but the shift is reversible upon CO removal. This observation suggests that the sulfate groups play an active role in defining the ligand sphere of both Ni2+ and Al3+ Lewis sites, and are flexible enough to allow the entrance of an additional molecule such as CO. 4.3 Reactivity towards C2H4 followed by spectroscopic methods Successively, the reactivity of the catalysts towards ethylene at room temperature was investigated by means of in situ FT-IR and DR UV-Vis spectroscopies, aimed to understand the initiation step and the deactivation mechanism. FT-IR spectra were recorded in the presence of ethylene at room temperature at a time resolution of 2 min and the reactivity was followed for 12 h. For bare γ-Al2O3, 8 wt%-NiO/γ-Al2O3 and 10 wt%-ReOx/γ-Al2O3 samples no changes were observed in the FT-IR spectra before and after introduction of ethylene, indicating that these samples are not active in ethylene conversion in agreement with previous results [22] (FT-IR spectra of oxide samples are not shown for clarity and reader are referred to literature where it has been reported that oxides and Ni-oxides/zeolites do not have considerable interaction with ethylene below 373 K at ambient/low pressures [80,81]). In contrast, FT-IR spectroscopy revealed that the sulfate containing samples including 8 wt%-(NH4)2SO4/γ-Al2O3, 8 wt%-NiSO4/γ-Al2O3, 8 wt%-NiSO4/8 wt%-ReOx/γ-Al2O3 and 8 wt%-ReOx/8 wt%-NiSO4/γ-Al2O3 are active towards ethylene. Since the interaction bands at C-H bending and stretching regions are only evolve in sulfate containing samples, it can be concluded that the presence of sulfate anions is fundamental to developing activity towards ethylene at room temperature. Fig. 6 shows the time-resolved FT-IR spectra collected within the first 4 h of reaction of 8 wt%-(NH4)2SO4/γ-Al2O3, 8 wt%-NiSO4/γ-Al2O3, and 8 wt%-NiSO4/8 wt%-ReOx/γ-Al2O3 samples with ethylene (equilibrium pressure PC2H4 = 10 mbar within the first 2 h, increased to 40 mbar in the successive 2 h). It is evident that the three catalysts behave in a different way, the 8 wt%-(NH4)2SO4/γ-Al2O3being the most diverse one. Starting the discussion from 8 wt%-(NH4)2SO4/γ-Al2O3 (Fig. 6ab), a complex series of absorption bands gradually grow up in the presence of ethylene, indicating the formation of saturated alkyl groups, and certainly of methyl groups. The spectra are characterized by three resolved absorption bands in the ν(CHx) region at 2960 cm-1 (νasym(CH3)), 2928 cm-1 (νasym(CH2)) and 2871 cm-1 (νsym(CH3)), along with a broad band due to the δasym(CH2) vibrational mode (a doublet at 1477 and 1468 cm-l). Moreover, two bands are grasped at 1383 and 1367 cm-l overlapped to the intense bands due to the vibrations of the sulfate anion, which are assigned to the δsym(CH3) vibrational mode of >C(CH3)2 species, and therefore are indicative of branching [57]. In addition to these absorption bands, two weak bands are observed around 1671 cm-1 and 1618 cm-1, which are likely due to ν(CC) vibrational modes [57,82]. All the above-mentioned absorption bands grow at the same rate along the whole investigated time interval, except for the band at 1618 cm-1, which appears immediately after contact with ethylene and then remains almost constant during the reaction. As a whole, the time-resolved FT-IR spectra indicate the formation of branched oligomers [83,84]. As a final observation, the very intense νasym(SO4) absorption band originally centered around 1400 cm-1 gradually downward shifts during the reaction of ethylene, indicating that the [SO4]2- anions are perturbed by the reaction products. In contrast, no great changes are observed in the ν(OH) region (not shown), where only the shoulder around 3710 cm-1 is eroded in favor of a band centered around 3650 cm-1, indicating that reactivity has to be ascribed mainly to Lewis and not Bronsted acidity. It is well known that sulfated alumina displays acidic properties and in general the presence of sulfate anions enhances the catalytic activity of alumina in acid-catalyzed reactions, such as olefin oligomerization and skeletal isomerization [85–88]. The accepted mechanism involves the formation of carbocationic species [86,89]. Carbocations may be generated in a number of ways, involving both Brønsted acid sites and Lewis acid sites. The products formed in the initiation stage are the thermodynamically more stable secondary or tertiary carbocations, and this explains why branched species are observed in our experiments. Propagation involves the repeated additions of ethylene to the carbocationic center, which in principle may migrate well away from the site of initial attack. Carbocations are very reactive species, and, in absence of super-acids, they terminate fast. The principal mechanism for termination is a chain-transfer process involving deprotonation of the carbocationic end-group by an incoming monomer, aided by the anion ([SO4]2- in our case). Sulfated alumina is not sufficiently acid to stabilize the carbocationic species and this justifies the observation of vinyl terminations (ν(CC) bands around 1650 cm-1). Moreover, it is also clear that sulfate anions play a vital role not only in enhancing the acidity of alumina, but also in guiding the termination process. The involvement of the [SO4]2- anions in the reaction is testified by the perturbation of the corresponding absorption bands. A different spectra evolution is observed for both 8 wt%-NiSO4/γ-Al2O3 and 8 wt%-NiSO4/8 wt%-ReOx/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. At short contact time, the FT-IR spectra are very similar to those observed for 8 wt%-(NH4)2SO4/γ-Al2O3catalyst, although less intense, witnessing the acid-catalyzed formation of branched oligomers. However, after about 30–40 min the absorption bands associated to vibrational modes involving CH2 groups start to grow faster (and slightly shift to lower wavenumber values) than those related to CH3 groups. The phenomenon is more evident for 8 wt%-NiSO4/γ-Al2O3 than for 8-Ni-8-Re. As a consequence, the spectra collected after 40 min of reaction resemble those of aliphatic hydrocarbons with linear chain-like structure and a few branches. Simultaneously, in the ν(CC) region the band at 1671 cm-1 grows at a higher rate than that at 1618 cm-1. The intense absorption band around 1400 cm-1 ascribed to νasym(SO4) vibration downward shifts even more than for the 8 wt%-(NH4)2SO4/γ-Al2O3 sample. The CH2/CH3 intensity ratio may give a rough estimation of the structure of the oligomeric products [82,90]. To this aim, the FT-IR spectra collected during ethylene reaction on the three catalysts were analyzed by curve-fitting in the 3000 – 2700 cm-1 region, by using five gaussian curves centered at 2960 cm-1 (νasym(CH3)), 2930 cm-1 (νasym(CH2)), 2900 cm-1 (ν(CH)), 2871 cm-1 (νsym(CH3)), and 2853 cm-1 (νsym(CH2)). A CH2/CH3 ratio was calculated based on the νasym(CH2) and νasym(CH3) bands at 2960 and 2930 cm-1 and the extinction coefficient of ε(CH3)/ε(CH2) is chosen as approximately 2.2 obtained from a reference measurement of n-heptane in CCl4 [83]. It is important to notice that the CH2/CH3 ratio only reflects an average value for a complex distribution of all the products and not a single product. An increase in the CH2/CH3 intensity ratio indicates that the aliphatic chains are becoming longer or less branched. In contrast, if the aliphatic chains are short or more branched, the CH2/CH3 ratio is low. The evolution of the CH2/CH3 ratio as a function of the reaction time is shown in Fig. 7. For 8 wt%-(NH4)2SO4/γ-Al2O3, the CH2/CH3 ratio maintains at approximate one during the whole reaction time, indicating that the nature of the branched oligomers remains constant. Attempts to extract the products of reactions failed, in that only ethylene was detected in the extraction solution. Hence, the acid catalyzed oligomerization products are difficult to extract, possibly because of cationic interaction with the catalyst surface. In contrast, for 8 wt%-NiSO4/γ-Al2O3 and 8 wt%-NiSO4/8 wt%-ReOx/γ-Al2O3 the CH2/CH3 ratio stays constant only during the first 40 min of reaction, followed by an increase, more pronounced for 8 wt%-NiSO4/γ-Al2O3 than for 8-Ni-8-Re. The different starting CH2/CH3 ratios of 8 wt%-NiSO4/γ-Al2O3 and 8 wt%-NiSO4/8 wt%-ReOx/γ-Al2O3 reflect the products of these acid-catalyzed reactions in dependence on the functional metal sites, which well supports the previous catalytic tests in a continuous flow reactor showing mainly butylene on 8 wt%-NiSO4/γ-Al2O3 and abundant propylene on 8 wt%-NiSO4/8 wt%-ReOx/γ-Al2O3 in the first 15 min. These data also indicate that after 40 min of reaction long-chain aliphatic hydrocarbons start to be formed and stick to the surface of both catalysts. These long hydrocarbon chains (which are stable also after prolonged degassing at room temperature) would be responsible for the fast deactivation previously observed in catalytic tests [22]. Formation of long-chain oligomers with a few branches on 8 wt%-NiSO4/γ-Al2O3 has been confirmed by GC-MS analysis of spent catalyst. Aliphatic products could be formed by an ethylene oligomerization reaction and a side dimerization or oligomerization reaction of olefinic products. Since Ni sites are responsible for formation of linear olefin products, it is believed that the long chain products are mainly attributed to the Ni sites. The comparatively little-increased rate of the CH2/CH3 ratio for 8 wt%-NiSO4/8 wt%-ReOx/γ-Al2O3 shows the formation of shorter chain length or more branched by-products, which indicates well the function of the Re sites for metathesis. The same experiment was followed by means of DR UV-Vis-NIR spectroscopy, which however reveals only very small changes during ethylene reaction at room temperature. Fig. 8 shows the most relevant DR UV-Vis-NIR spectra for the 8 wt%-NiSO4/γ-Al2O3 sample as an example. Similar spectra were collected for the other catalysts as shown in Fig. S2. Upon ethylene dosage in the reaction cell, very few changes are observed in the DR UV-Vis-NIR spectrum: the d-d bands centered around 7000 and 17,000 cm-1 slightly decrease in intensity, while the charge transfer band around 35,000 cm-1 increases. Accordingly, the coordination environment of the Ni sites changes only slightly in the presence of ethylene. This observation, which seems in contrast with the expected increase in the ligand field around the Ni sites upon ethylene adsorption, might be explained in terms of ligand displacement, i.e. ethylene displays other ligands (the sulfate anions) originally present around the Ni sites, in agreement with the FT-IR results. After prolonged reaction time, a weak band appears around 25,000 cm-1, which may be assigned to a carbocationic species containing conjugated double-bonds [91,92]. 4.4 Investigation of the oxidation state in spent catalysts FT-IR experiments were continued by sending CO at 100 K to the spent catalysts after the ethylene reaction overnight. The aim of this experiment was to investigate possible changes in Ni and acid sites after the catalytic reaction. Fig. 9 shows the spectra of CO adsorbed over three spent catalysts. The overall intensity of all the spectra in Fig. 9 is much lower than that observed for just activated catalysts (Fig. 4), indicating that most of the adsorption sites are no more available for CO adsorption. This is because the long-chain products formed on the active sites during the reaction are difficult to be removed by simple evacuation at room temperature. In addition, bands of ≡ Al-OH···CO and ≡ Al3+···CO adducts at around 2200 and 2170 cm-1 shift to lower wavenumbers after reaction, indicating that both Brønsted and Lewis acidities decrease during the reaction. The decrease of acidity may be explained by a ligand displacement between ethylene and sulfate ions. It is important to notice that no Ni+ carbonyl band is observed in the spectra of all spent catalyst. Thus, oxidation state of Ni remains Ni2+ after the reaction. The oxidation state of the spent catalyst was also tested by XPS. The spectrum of the spent catalyst ( Fig. 10a, spectrum 2) keeps the same line patterns as that of the fresh catalyst (Fig. 10 Spectrum 1), although all the bands appear slightly shifted to a higher binding energy. The shift cannot account for a change in the Ni oxidation state, rather it reflects that the electronic structure of the Ni ions is affected by the presence of adjacent surface ligands (either sulphate ions or surface hydroxyl groups). Similarly, the small differences observed in the spectra of the activated catalyst and the spent catalyst can be explained by the displacement of the surface ions/surface hydroxyl groups induced by the products formed during the reaction. ESR experiment was carried out as well in order to examine the oxidation state of the 8 wt%-NiSO4/γ-Al2O3 catalyst in the course of the reaction. 100 mbar of ethylene were admitted at room temperature on the catalyst activates at 673 K. The spectrum of 8 wt%-NiSO4/γ-Al2O3 during the reaction (Fig. 10b, spectra 1–3) are the same as those of pristine 8 wt%-NiSO4/γ-Al2O3 (Fig. 10, spectra 2 and 3). Hence, Ni+ is not observed even on the active catalyst during the reaction. 5 Conclusion We have carried out a systematic spectroscopic investigation of the molecular structure and functions in a bimetallic NiSO4/ReOx/γ-Al2O3 catalyst which performs the direct conversion of ethylene to propylene at mild reaction conditions (323 K, 1 atm). Our own and literature results [22,23,25] conclude that ethylene is dimerized/isomerized to 2-butylene over a site requiring both Ni and sulfate ions, while the Re sites are responsible for the ethylene-butylene metathesis reaction, resulting in the tandem production of propylene. Albeit highly selective, the catalyst deactivates fast. Since deactivation is driven by the ethylene dimerization reaction, in this work we put focus on the molecular investigation of the NiSO4 site, with the aim to understand the changes occurring at the NiSO4 sites during the catalyst activation, and in presence of ethylene. A series of NiSO4-ReOx/Al2O3 catalysts differing in the relative amount of the two functions were synthetized, tested in the ETP reaction, and thoroughly characterized by means of FT-IR, DR UV-Vis-NIR, XPS and ESR spectroscopies, before and after thermal activation and during/after reaction with ethylene. It was found that the sulfate ions play an essential role in increasing the acidity of the Al2O3 surface (as demonstrated by FT-IR spectroscopy of CO adsorbed at 100 K), and also in influencing the electronic structure of the Ni cations. During thermal catalyst activation the sulfate ions are covalently bonded either to Ni2+ or/and Al3+ cations. In contrast to earlier reports [23,25], the Ni cations retain the + 2 oxidation state also after the catalyst activation step and after the ETP reaction, as shown directly by DR UV-Vis-NIR, ESR and XPS analysis, and indirectly by FT-IR spectroscopy of CO adsorbed at 100 K. Therefore, we conclude that the oxidation state of active Ni sites is + 2. FT-IR experiments performed in the presence of ethylene at room temperature and low pressure (40 mbar) allowed to monitor the initial steps of the reaction on the different catalysts. It was proved that sulfated alumina promotes the slow formation of branched hydrocarbons through a carbocationic mechanism. The sulfate ions covalently bonded to the Ni2+ (or Al3+) sites are partially displaced during the reaction, as testified by the perturbation of the corresponding IR absorption bands. In presence of the Ni2+ function, formation of long chain hydrocarbons is observed at longer reaction times. We conclude that deactivation of the NiSO4-ReOx/Al2O3 catalysts is mainly the consequence of adsorption of higher linear ethylene oligomers or due to Ni2+ sites not being anymore in interaction with the sulfate ions. Improvements in the catalyst lifetime could be achieved by limiting the mobility of the sulfate anions or utilizing another reactor technology, such as e.g. a slurry reactor [27]. coredata.dc:description: A series of NiSO4-ReOx/Al2O3 catalysts were synthesized by a co-impregnation method, tested in the conversion of ethylene to propylene at mild conditions, and thoroughly characterized by different spectroscopy techniques. In particular, the attention was focused on the NiSO4 function, which is directly involved in ethylene conversion to 2-butylene, but also drives the catalyst deactivation. Results shows that the sulfate anions increase the surface acidity of alumina, and simultaneously influence the electronic properties of the Ni sites. Indeed, thermal activation of the catalyst promotes the formation of covalent bonds between the sulfate anions and the Ni2+ or Al3+ cations, while keeping constant the + 2 oxidation state of the Ni sites. Studying the initial steps of the ETP reaction reveals the primary acid-catalyzed formation of branched oligomers. Catalyst deactivation could be due to formation and adsorption of long-chain oligomers, or less interaction of sulfate anions with Ni ions.
